importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when demolition of the White House East Wing officially began, marking the start of President Trump's new ballroom project.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period when President Trump first announced the 15-year ambition to build a state ballroom, with construction beginning in October 2025.

keyTakeAways: Demolition of the White House East Wing began on October 20, 2025, to make way for a new $200 million, 90,000-square-foot ballroom.
The new ballroom is designed with gold and crystal chandeliers, gilded columns, a coffered ceiling, and a checkered marble floor, echoing Trump’s aesthetic of private clubs.
The ballroom will seat 650 people — more than three times the capacity of the current East Room — and will be built on land previously housing first ladies' offices.
The project is framed as fulfilling a 15-year ambition by President Trump to expand the White House’s entertaining capacity.
The White House claims the new space maintains the neoclassical architectural heritage of the building.
Trump asserts there are no zoning restrictions and that the project can proceed immediately due to his executive authority.
The White House has responded to criticism by referencing past renovations during the Truman administration, emphasizing that construction has always been part of the White House’s evolution.
The project draws comparisons to Trump’s private clubs and is seen as a symbol of his personal style and influence over the White House's appearance and function.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Demolition of the White House East Wing began on October 20, 2025, as part of a $200 million project to build a 90,000-square-foot, state ballroom designed to seat 650 people. The initiative, long touted by President Donald Trump as a 15-year ambition, will replace the space historically used by first ladies and will feature a luxurious, gilded aesthetic reminiscent of Trump’s private clubs. The ballroom will maintain the neoclassical heritage of the White House, while marking a significant shift in the building’s function and appearance. Trump emphasized that the project has no zoning restrictions and can proceed immediately due to presidential authority. The White House has defended the demolition by referencing past renovations during the Truman administration, claiming that modernization is a necessary and historical part of the White House’s evolution. Critics have raised concerns about the scale and impact of the changes, but officials have dismissed such criticism as 'pearl clutching'.
title: Demolition begins to replace White House East Wing with Trump’s ballroom
